title: Man lured to Grindr date by teens who ambushed him in homophobic attack
text:
Marc Power was ambushed by teens in a homophobic attack (Picture: Marc Power)

A man who arranged to meet a date on Grindr was ambushed by hammer wielding teens in a suspected premeditated homophobic attack.

Marc Power, from Dublin, was lured to the assault on Tuesday night by what he believes to have been a fake profile on the gay dating app Grindr.

He was sitting in his car at the arranged meeting spot outside the Odeon Cinema when four young men attempted to drag him out of his car, punching his face and legs and branding him a ‘pervert’ and a ‘f****t’.

He told the Irish Times: ‘I pulled into a spot, then a group of teenagers seemed to come out of a bush and rushed towards the car.

‘They started punching me in the face, one must have been wearing a ring on his finger as I started bleeding everywhere.

‘They started calling me a f****t, calling me a paedophile, a pervert. They were all laughing, that was one of the scariest things about it. Right away they were trying to get me in the head’.

Mr Power, who is in his early 50s, said he believed the teens were trying to murder him.

Marc Power thought he was meeting a date but instead was attacked by teens (Picture: Marc Power)

The teens fled when bystanders noticed the attack, and the victim was taken to hospital.

He said his car was destroyed in the attack and shared graphic images of his injuries on Facebook.

He described himself as a ‘private person’ but said he wanted to speak out about the attack to prevent something similar to happening to someone else.

He said: ‘I’ve lived abroad most of my life and never had any problems. Back in Ireland I’ve had about three incidents. It makes me think about my own home city, and has it changed much. I’ve no issues with my sexuality; other people do.’

Garda (Police) arrived at the scene about 10 minutes after the attack.

Mr Power was given an appointment for Wednesday next week to give a full statement and said he was disappointed it wasn’t treated with more urgency.

A spokesperson from Garda said investigations were ongoing.

He thought the teens were trying to murder him (Picture: Marc Power)

Mr Power said the incident would make him wearier of meeting up with people in the future, but he insisted he would not allow the assault to ‘change who I am’.

However, he criticised Gridnr for allowing people to open fake accounts.

A spokesperson from the dating app said they were ‘heartbroken’ to hear about the incident and insisted they take measures to protect their users.

They added: ‘We consistently look for ways to strengthen how we protect our users.’

The Irish government are facing mounting pressure from LGBTQ+ organisations to introduce legislation making attacks motivated by homophobia or racism a hate crime.

A spokesman for the Department of Justice told the Irish Times research was being undertaken to look at how other countries had legislated for hate crimes.

description: Marc Power from Dublin was the victim of a homophobic attack after arranging a date on gay app Grindr
